page.title: 02Bideford:S+SE.Landscape.
page.content: The River Torridge, makes a 1km.wide meander to the east about the middle of the area,after which it is joined by the R.Yeo,a small tributary from the south-west.The tidal nature of both rivers explains the dramatic changes in scenery and atmosphere occurring throughout the day.At full tide when the saltmarshes,located mainly on the eastern side of the Torridge ,are flood -ed,the normal width of the river of 10- 20 yds.,is increased to c.200 yds.. The valley sides of both rivers rise sharply,close to the rivers in most pla -ces,to heights of 300-375 ft.,and in- accessibility is probably the main reas -on for the survival here of areas of deciduous woodland,amounting in all to about 1sq.km..Jennett's Reservoir in the extreme mid-west of the area is par -ticularly interesting , pulsing with life and energy.
